meta.description: Cutting-edge wellness advice from doctors, vetted travel recommendations, and a curated shop of clean beauty, fashion, and home.

title: goop | A modern lifestyle brand.
cleaned_text:
10 Days in Sicily (and What I Packed) Get ready for the freshest, juiciest tomato you’ve ever tasted, a candy-colored sunset over the sparkling blue sea, and the most gorgeous ancient architecture you’ve ever laid eyes on. Here’s where I stayed, ate, shopped, and explored—and what I brought with me. skip to end of carousel link

This Glow Routine Starts the Night Before Interior design entrepreneur Ashley Stark hits the ground running practically the second she wakes up. Part of the secret is that some of her “morning” routine is already done. skip to end of carousel link

How to Double Cleanse—and Why Skin Loves It If you wear makeup or sunscreen, live where pollution is a concern, or just feel the way you currently cleanse isn’t cutting it, double cleansing might be your answer (no matter your skin type). skip to end of carousel link

10 Tips for Beachy, Healthy-Looking Skin—from a Kombucha Queen “I’m 38, but my skin looks better now than it did when I was 28,” says Amy Driscoll, the Brooklyn-based cofounder of Bear’s Fruit, a line of fizzy kombuchas and fruity sparkling waters with probiotics geared toward boosting gut health. She chalks up her happy skin to her probiotic drinks, a skin routine heavy on the antioxidants, and subtle makeup that mimics a healthy vacation glow. skip to end of carousel link

Healing—and Finding Love—after Dating a Narcissist “Being romantically involved with a narcissist can wreak havoc on your sense of self, distort your reality, and decimate your self-esteem,” writes relationship coach Ezzie Spencer, PhD. For clients coming off the heels of a narcissistic relationship, Spencer helps them reconnect with their intuition, move forward, and find lasting love. skip to end of carousel link

Cheryl Strayed on Being Brave Enough to Break Your Own Heart “So much of life is staying open to our own bewilderment,” says Cheryl Strayed. This week, Cleo Wade sits down with the Wild author to talk about the origins of the beloved advice column, Dear Sugar, and what she’s learned through writing about loss, connection, and self-forgiveness. (Tiny Beautiful Things, the show based on Strayed’s book, is out now on Hulu.) skip to end of carousel link
